question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about public policy which was something I hadn't focused on here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about what arts policy was, from the history of it to how it relates to my everyday life. I also learned great project-based skills like time management and communication. Furthermore, I learned how to write a policy brief, which is something I didn't know how to do before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical analysis of policies and institutions - i.e. considering how institutions are created and situated, and how this impacts the people attracted to this institution and how that institution is perceived

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to build knowledge in U.S. public policy, art and the intersection of both in a very engaging and practical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding of public arts policy decision-making

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reviewed case studies in arts leadership, visited local cultural organizations, and discussed the challenges facing the arts today. A central component of the course was the extended engagement with a community partner, so we developed our collaborative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about art in a different and new context. I also learned professional skills through the service learning aspect of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cultural and arts policies, and how we can observe the phenomenons of these policies in real life. I gained insight on the impacts of cultural and arts policy, and how each action affects the communities around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned more about all different aspects of art policy
2. Learned how the arts directly spur economic activity
3. How to collaborate professionally in a workplace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically I learned how to analysis and interpret arts policy in the real world today and apply my leadership knowledge in unique ways to make a difference both in Durham and my local community here at Duke. I learned how to critically engage with peers about arts policy and discuss with them. Lastly, I learned how to work with community partners to ensure long-term success.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nurkin was incredibly engaged and kind to his students!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was one of my favorites so far at duke. Professor Nurkin is extremely engaging, and he makes learning fun! I had no prior knowledge of arts policy, yet he managed to keep me engaged the whole time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the small group discussions, and community building class excursions helped me feel comfortable and excited to learn and engage with the material

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I greatly appreciated how the course began with establishing a solid theoretical framework, which we then continuously applied to practical scenarios. The instructor's engaging approach, thoughtful questioning, and attentive listening fostered a dynamic and inclusive learning environment.​

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The absolute free-for-all structure of the discussions really helped me open up. I was never afraid to share my opinion, instead maybe I was more hesitant by ruminating and tweaking how I was going to say an idea. It also helped a very natural dialogue that was insightful. This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. I know there were 6-7 key yappers, but in a class with more shy people or only a few key people speaking, it would be much more anxious/forced.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Class visits and excursions

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don’t feel afraid to take this class if you do not have a lot of experience with theatre. It is really accessible to non-thespians. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: That the class is is a lot of outside work which may be cumbersome if you also have a class that eats up a lot of your time. Overall though, if you have any interest in theater or management the class is very interesting. If you have no background in theater the class does cover most of what you would need to know. The knowledge gained from the class can be applicable in areas outside of theater as well, so it is still worthwhile. The class is pretty chill and Thom is very approachable, plus you get to enjoy two comped shows, one at the DPAC with a Q&A session with the cast and crew after, and another with the Duke Theater Studies Show. Additionally, Thom lines up a good selection of guest speakers with quality inside knowledge and stories which were interesting every time. For those reasons I recommend the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to explore knowledge stored within the body which was a nice change of pace from the traditional academic course. I learned different dance styles including vouging, capoeira, and swing. I also learned about different historical players in the making of these dance styles and the ways that dance influences and is influenced by a given social and political climate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned what embodiment of dance was, I learned several different dance styles including swing, hiphop, and capoeira, lastly I learned how to connect my embodied experience to academic literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyse theatre critically and (somewhat) objectively, some of the history of theatre in London, and what it means to be a tourist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Mcdisney, place-myth, public transportation

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed stronger skills in analyzing my surroundings in relation to my own personal experiences.
I gained a wider view of art, through multiple mediums, and gained comprehension of my own artistic goals and desires. 
I learned how to frame conversations that provide effective discussion without discrediting people's opinions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Cross-cultural analysis of London's arts scene and the United States (theater, dance, visual arts, street art, etc.)
- The effects of government subsidization and other funding sources on arts production
- Evaluating art from both a disciplinary and personal perspective (and combining those two perspectives into ethnographic research)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I honed my abilities to analyze performances and art, and tie them to readings when the focus is on the performance themselves. I learned more about engaging with other cultures, what makes a performance successful/unsuccessful, and also had a great time!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach theatre, art, tourism, and global communities in New ways. I learned how to evaluate productions. I also learned how to evaluate my place in London.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Artistic evaluation as a discipline
Cultural influences on art (and how that changes art when it is brought to a new environment)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to view tourism and travelling through and ethnographic research lens, how to critically engage with and evaluate art, and how to connect arts and culture. I engaged with the arts in a new and intellectually stimulating way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the arts and tourism scene in London, as well as how to navigate the streets, food, and culture of London. Additionally, through experiencing a vast number of shows I learned elements of what makes a production successful and new ways of producing theatre that I hadn’t seen before. I also learned about my comfort living in a large city as a potential place for living after college.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding for the art of theater and developed a skill to critique the art, understand it on a better level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how we would see shows and then discuss them extensively in class, often connecting them to the previous night's readings. I also really liked the presentations, as I felt more prepared to go into the spaces we were talking about in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Excursions were superb and family meals were a must-keep

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Torry was phenomenal at keeping discussions on track while also allowing for us to guide it. The structure of attending excursions while having readings relevant to the excursions worked really well. Our discussions were able to be open and genuine because of the environment that was constructed. I would recommend keeping the course as excursion and class based.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed most of the readings and having a platform to discuss the cultural experiences we'd had outside of class within the academic environment. I thought the balance of experiences like museums and shows with in-class work was handled really well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Please keep the excursion journals! They really helped me keep track of what had happened every week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Keep class discussions controversial but not polarized xoxo

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Bend was encouraging, understanding, kind, and just overall an excellent professor. She asked questions that were stimulating and sparked great discussions. The balance of lectures and out-of-class excursions was great. I felt like I got to experience a lot outside of class and then digest it within class with my peers and professor. I really enjoyed this structure and thought it was a perfect balance of fun and learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was extremely beneficial being able to see shows together and discuss its significance both to us and to the greater context of arts in London. I would keep immersive Guys and Dolls, Spirited Away, and School for Scandal (if they are still playing in future years). I also appreciate classes ending at noon so that we were able to see matinees and evening shows on the same day as classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Tory was amazing. That made me excited to come to class and to continue to immerse myself in that environment.

response_text: This is such a fun experience! London is an incredible city. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The process of designing lights for a theatrical production, a greater appreciation for the role that lighting plays in everyday life, and the specific software, jargon, and methodologies used by theatrical lighting designers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the theory of how to light theater and dance performances, how to use software to implement this theory, and how to physically hang and focus lights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Developing a plan to augment a theatrical performance using lighting design
- Using lighting design software used in industry. Specifically how to patch, program, and change lighting units using the EOS software.
- Learned about the different types of theater lights, when to use them, and their positions on the stage. Talked about the effects that different types of intensity, movement, and light color can have on a performance's mood and atmosphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned the technical aspects that go into a lighting design such as color, intensity and position.
2. I learned how to hang lights within a theater.
3. I learned how to successfully use eos software to program the lights in a theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed understanding of common terminology in lighting design and technical theater as well as an understanding of the general design and application process of light in a theatrical production. The course has a nice balance of the amount of hand-on experience and lecture, providing me equal opportunities to learn the terminology of the field and to develop a better sense of how the process really looks like. I have also got the opportunity to see the creative process of professionals working in the field of light design as well as the professional standard for associated paperwork in the industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use an ETC lighting console, how to hang and focus lights, and learned about the qualities and functions of light and practiced making lighting designs based on all this. I feel much more competent with all the equipment and theory than I did at the beginning of the class. Learned about moving lights as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very down to earth and accessible, which made me feel more engaged in the coursework and that he was personally invested in my learning. I would definitely keep all of the in-class light board work and demonstrations, since it allowed me to better visualize and work through things on my own.

The topics were all incredibly stimulating, and because we were covering such a broad field of knowledge, I felt we could have been given more of a challenge to chew on in order to cover more of that field. More listening opportunities might also have been useful, maybe a mandatory field trip to a show or having student presentations on shows they'd been to?

-I would have appreciated more instructor lectures on the technical and conceptual decisions in sound design, especially in the beginning of the semester
-Bringing us into the theater for the show was super engaging and I learned a lot being in the actual theater space

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course encouraged alternative forms of engagement with the material in both the content of the course and the way the class was facilitated. Specifically, several of the texts in class repositioned or introduced ways of theorizing the body, and being able to hear directly from the author (Eli Clare and Anathea Poitier Young visit, Susan Foster video, Ashon Crawley talk, etc.) was deeply insightful. The text activation was also valuable in making me thing of alternative ways to engage with academic texts and rethink the role of the body in academic spaces.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say make sure you are ready to expand your thinking and, at times, out of your comfort zone.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course if you are considering to learn more about corporeality/body/gender/postcolonial theories. This class is super helpful, and it is both an academic-friendly and a practice-friendly class, meaning that students of all types of studies will learn many things in this class. Sarah and Jingqiu both give very reflective and detailed comments and they are both helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course offers an excellent, supportive, and intellectually simulating environment to dedicate time to developing a particular method of study or topic of study that involved theorizing the body.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Thinking of historiography from the perspective of bodies and included/excluded narratives
- How to analyze a text for discussion
- the artist colonization process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the body and performance must be recognized as a vital source of knowledge production.I developed skills in thinking about and representing my research in different ways: drawing it out, writing about it in a stream-of-consciousness manner, activating a text I am working with through movement, and more.I adopted the thought process that endings are a social construct and sometimes the work comes to a temporary stopping point, but it is always developing whether you work on it or not. I feel more comfortable with the mentality that things will always be unfinished and I can always return to them when inspiration strikes again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How the body has been ignored and forgotten in much of academic scholarship and how the written word has and still dominates what knowledge is valued (Spatz, Foster, Hartman)
How power is subverted and claimed in ways that the colonial gaze misses or misconstrues  (Mahmood, Taylor)
How scholars, artists, and ourselves are challenging notions of objective, rational fact as truth ~ bringing in creative writing, movement, performance and interdisciplinary thinking into our work

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The reading discussions were top notch.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The text activations were extremely effective in my engagement with each text. The first one we did felt like enough. If we had done two, I think it may have been too much.I was especially engaged with the text activation about the punching, slashing, floating, etc. that Professor Wilbur offered. It was an incredibly useful visual that I return to when thinking about my word choices and each position I take in a paper.I really appreciated the alteration of the classroom setup. It was mentally stimulating to sit in a new spot every day and it helped me get connected to other students in class.The accountability structure for the final project was well-timed for me. I grew more comfortable with sharing work in the development stages, which I feel made my paper stronger.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Text activations were memorable and helpful for digestion
Readings were awesome overall!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be increasingly aware of the way societal systems norm us and how we are subject to those normative ideologies; I learned how to connect and tap into my body as a means of thought; I practices the skill of thinking in an imaginative and creative way to approach social change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked this class because I learned a lot about social injustices and social problems. Three things that I learned that really resonated with me are the connection between how diabled people are treated and the treatment of animals, the act up movement in the 80s and 90s surrounding HIV/AIDS, and how some children are at a huge disadvantage when it comes to access to education.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about how movement is a form of communication and can be used for activism, thought, and expression. We also learned a lot about different activist groups and what they did. We also learned how to think outside the box of what we think of as normal when it comes to restructuring and changing the systems we have in place to try to better our society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to have productive discourse on politically motivated topics, particularly in an environment with various opinions on certain subjects. I also learned much about the connection between thought, emotion, and movement. To add to that, I understand my body and how I can utilize moving it as a tool to gain a deeper understanding of myself and my perceived environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to use my body to think and what it means to "embody" concepts. I feel more connected to my body now. I also learned what the "soma" is and how philosophy, ethics, and neuroscience can inform how we process trauma, think, and perpetuate societal norms. I also know much more about the AIDS movement, criminal justice reform and reparations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into what types of issues are out in the world and I got to develop my perspective on those illuminating problems. I learned how to think outside of the box and be creative in thinking up solutions to change the narrative, the societal norms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problem-solving skills, knowledge of current events and topics that are currently affecting society, and insight into how these problems can be solved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really made me think about my life and the position I'm in. It really made me want to be more aware of what is happening around me, especially what is going on in the scenes around social injustice and art. I learned a lot about the history of social injustices like sexism, racism, and classism. This class helped me to think using my body and know what it feels like to getting closer to merging the mind and body into one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a hardcore STEM enthusiast, I never in my life thought I would sit through a small public policy seminar during my first semester of college. But, looking in retrospect, this seminar was my one of my favorite classes that I have taken. First, I learned to think outside the "norm." During class, we called our professors by their first names and sat on bean bags and wool carpets instead of chairs. We had wild discussions ranging from prison abolition to using our body to connect with our thoughts ("dance is thought"). These discussions made me think outside the box and realize that if I continue to imagine the seemingly radical ideas, maybe one day it will become a reality. Secondly, I learned how to analyze texts and lead discussions/debates that differed from my personal, political, and ethical views. Our discussion section was very close-knit and welcoming, and I learned to value not only sharing my own opinions but also listening to other's viewpoints and peacefully debating controversial topics. Finally, I learned the value of exploring various ways to approach radical ideas. For instance, throughout class, we used our body to get in touch with our radical view of the world. This was very stimulating and eye-opening in that movement can change our thoughts and be used as a vehicle to explore the most radical ideas that are subconsciously in our brain.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very available to talk, and facilitated deeply thought provoking discussions throughout each class and through the reading. This allowed me to analyze to a deeper level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that they definately did a good job having us engage in class. It was refreshing to have teachers who also spoke about their opinions and ideas in class as well as leaving space for us students to discuss. the class was definitely not lecture based which I appreciated. It was a conversation between everyone including our professors which I really liked.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors did a great job of pushing our thinking to the next level by always asking us questions to deepen our thoughts. They also did fun things in the dance studio, like setting up sculptures and art around it to create an environment that pushes the boundaries of what we see as normal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think this class did a fabulous job of balancing productive discourse with artistic elements of movement. Having an approximately 50/50 split between discussions and movement breaks kept the class interesting, informative, and fun. I would say the overall structure of the class is refreshing from the typical lecture style, so I recommend keeping it the same in future classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the class felt conversational and the instructors were overall very open to new ideas or even tangential conversations. I also liked that we were able to call them by their first names as it created a greater sense of intimacy. I also appreciated that the class was held in a dance studio as it was a great canvas to build upon as we moved, built, and imagined.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The ways the instructors facilitate my learning by giving me the opportunity to learn on my own in a capacity of no-hand holding of figuring out what is important to me and what I as an individual can do in the here and now. I love the weekly reflections of seeing different modes and solutions to societal issues that impact us in a small or little way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructors made classroom environment very comfortable and safe, applying unconventional methods (like sitting on the floor, setting up classroom in a strange way, referring to profs by first name, and using movement to engage the body and the mind during class time) to challenge what is deemed "normal". I liked the casual, comfortable environment of the class and felt that it helped students engage more with the material and think outside the box.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The part of the course that I really enjoyed the most was the movement exercises that we did. We were lead in an exercise typically meant to bridge the gap between body and mind and use our imaginations to do so. We were challenged to do movements we've never felt before and experience new feelings. The instructors used these exercises to expand our imaginations. We learned what it was like to imagine new ideas from the texts that we read in class and how people in the past have really thought outside of the box in order to address social injustices. The instructors gave us a good amount of reading material but let us interpret our own understanding in discussion posts. I think I would keep these same methods of instruction in the future, except that some weeks had a large amount of reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both instructors were very very VERY welcoming, friendly, and easy to approach. I even turned to Brookes for personal advice and had a conversation about my love for arts and how I could explore that throughout college. The professors were genuinely SO caring about each and every one of their students, and I will always be on a lookout if they teach more courses in the future. They not only helped me grow as a student and a thinker, but as a person.

response_text: I really appreciated the readings—it was nice to get a new perspective and information on some social justice concepts I don't interact with every day. I also appreciated the different art projects the instructors presented at the beginning of some of the classes.

response_text: This course was most stimulating to me because it covered topics that were new and proposed viewpoints I hadn't looked through.

response_text: This class was one of the most stimulating classes I have taken in my life. It was very stimulating in that the class was set inside a dance studio and the whole premise of the course being about breaking the norms of the society.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to move and go outside of your comfort zone! You will learn a lot about social issues in a thorough way, which better prepares you to engage with/understand the world, the news, and current events.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the course is definitely so interesting and not like any other class I've ever taken. I would tell the student that you have to engage in some uncomfortable things but ultimately they make you more aware of yourself and how you take up space in the world around you. I would also warn them that there is a lot of reading and it does take a lot of time out of your day.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is not much work, but it is a lot of fun. The professors and the course are pretty liberal and focus on social justice issues. If you do not care about social justice a lot, I recommend not taking the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not the typical learning style most Duke students are used to. If you excel in lecture-based classes, this will be outside of your comfort zone. However, there are a lot of benefits to inhabiting a different kind of learning environment and I feel the skills I gained from this class, in terms of discussing politics and being in touch with my body, can be harnessed beyond the seminar.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is definitely not your typical Duke class. I appreciated it because it was a refreshing departure from some of my more "normative" large lecture courses. However, be prepared to push your thinking. Be prepared to be uncomfortable, embarrassed, confused, inspired. There is more reading than I expected.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was amazing in opening my mind to the real world and providing a break from the college structure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will definitely push you to escape the limitations of your comfort zone. There may be times where you will feel uncomfortable with the movements and physical activities conducted in the class, but ultimately if you engage, you will learn and grow as a student and as a thinker and activist. Teachers do a good job ensuring that the classroom is a safe space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage students to take this course because it helps them to realize the situation they are in and how to use your imagination to work for a better future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will change the way you think and view radical ideas. One quote from Brookes and the reading that will forever stick with me is "dance is thought." As a dancer, this quote stays in my heart as I perform and practice every time. I have always battled internally whether my movements lead to my dance moves or my movements led to the feeling of liberation I always have when I'm dancing. But through this course, I realized that dance is purely just my thinking; movement is thought. This course taught me how to view my dancing career and also imagine for liberation. As the professors said, radical imaginations are always needed for real change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be increasingly aware of the way societal systems norm us and how we are subject to those normative ideologies; I learned how to connect and tap into my body as a means of thought; I practices the skill of thinking in an imaginative and creative way to approach social change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked this class because I learned a lot about social injustices and social problems. Three things that I learned that really resonated with me are the connection between how diabled people are treated and the treatment of animals, the act up movement in the 80s and 90s surrounding HIV/AIDS, and how some children are at a huge disadvantage when it comes to access to education.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about how movement is a form of communication and can be used for activism, thought, and expression. We also learned a lot about different activist groups and what they did. We also learned how to think outside the box of what we think of as normal when it comes to restructuring and changing the systems we have in place to try to better our society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to have productive discourse on politically motivated topics, particularly in an environment with various opinions on certain subjects. I also learned much about the connection between thought, emotion, and movement. To add to that, I understand my body and how I can utilize moving it as a tool to gain a deeper understanding of myself and my perceived environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to use my body to think and what it means to "embody" concepts. I feel more connected to my body now. I also learned what the "soma" is and how philosophy, ethics, and neuroscience can inform how we process trauma, think, and perpetuate societal norms. I also know much more about the AIDS movement, criminal justice reform and reparations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into what types of issues are out in the world and I got to develop my perspective on those illuminating problems. I learned how to think outside of the box and be creative in thinking up solutions to change the narrative, the societal norms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problem-solving skills, knowledge of current events and topics that are currently affecting society, and insight into how these problems can be solved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really made me think about my life and the position I'm in. It really made me want to be more aware of what is happening around me, especially what is going on in the scenes around social injustice and art. I learned a lot about the history of social injustices like sexism, racism, and classism. This class helped me to think using my body and know what it feels like to getting closer to merging the mind and body into one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a hardcore STEM enthusiast, I never in my life thought I would sit through a small public policy seminar during my first semester of college. But, looking in retrospect, this seminar was my one of my favorite classes that I have taken. First, I learned to think outside the "norm." During class, we called our professors by their first names and sat on bean bags and wool carpets instead of chairs. We had wild discussions ranging from prison abolition to using our body to connect with our thoughts ("dance is thought"). These discussions made me think outside the box and realize that if I continue to imagine the seemingly radical ideas, maybe one day it will become a reality. Secondly, I learned how to analyze texts and lead discussions/debates that differed from my personal, political, and ethical views. Our discussion section was very close-knit and welcoming, and I learned to value not only sharing my own opinions but also listening to other's viewpoints and peacefully debating controversial topics. Finally, I learned the value of exploring various ways to approach radical ideas. For instance, throughout class, we used our body to get in touch with our radical view of the world. This was very stimulating and eye-opening in that movement can change our thoughts and be used as a vehicle to explore the most radical ideas that are subconsciously in our brain.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very available to talk, and facilitated deeply thought provoking discussions throughout each class and through the reading. This allowed me to analyze to a deeper level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that they definately did a good job having us engage in class. It was refreshing to have teachers who also spoke about their opinions and ideas in class as well as leaving space for us students to discuss. the class was definitely not lecture based which I appreciated. It was a conversation between everyone including our professors which I really liked.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors did a great job of pushing our thinking to the next level by always asking us questions to deepen our thoughts. They also did fun things in the dance studio, like setting up sculptures and art around it to create an environment that pushes the boundaries of what we see as normal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think this class did a fabulous job of balancing productive discourse with artistic elements of movement. Having an approximately 50/50 split between discussions and movement breaks kept the class interesting, informative, and fun. I would say the overall structure of the class is refreshing from the typical lecture style, so I recommend keeping it the same in future classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the class felt conversational and the instructors were overall very open to new ideas or even tangential conversations. I also liked that we were able to call them by their first names as it created a greater sense of intimacy. I also appreciated that the class was held in a dance studio as it was a great canvas to build upon as we moved, built, and imagined.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The ways the instructors facilitate my learning by giving me the opportunity to learn on my own in a capacity of no-hand holding of figuring out what is important to me and what I as an individual can do in the here and now. I love the weekly reflections of seeing different modes and solutions to societal issues that impact us in a small or little way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructors made classroom environment very comfortable and safe, applying unconventional methods (like sitting on the floor, setting up classroom in a strange way, referring to profs by first name, and using movement to engage the body and the mind during class time) to challenge what is deemed "normal". I liked the casual, comfortable environment of the class and felt that it helped students engage more with the material and think outside the box.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The part of the course that I really enjoyed the most was the movement exercises that we did. We were lead in an exercise typically meant to bridge the gap between body and mind and use our imaginations to do so. We were challenged to do movements we've never felt before and experience new feelings. The instructors used these exercises to expand our imaginations. We learned what it was like to imagine new ideas from the texts that we read in class and how people in the past have really thought outside of the box in order to address social injustices. The instructors gave us a good amount of reading material but let us interpret our own understanding in discussion posts. I think I would keep these same methods of instruction in the future, except that some weeks had a large amount of reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both instructors were very very VERY welcoming, friendly, and easy to approach. I even turned to Brookes for personal advice and had a conversation about my love for arts and how I could explore that throughout college. The professors were genuinely SO caring about each and every one of their students, and I will always be on a lookout if they teach more courses in the future. They not only helped me grow as a student and a thinker, but as a person.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The deep conversations, the lack of normativity in the teaching style, and the engaging and comprehensive discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was extremely stimulating because we talked about so many different and interesting things that really made us think and form opinions. As I said before, there was a lot of talk about social justice issues and issues that plague the world so talking about those definitely got me thinking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is not much work, but it is a lot of fun. The professors and the course are pretty liberal and focus on social justice issues. If you do not care about social justice a lot, I recommend not taking the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not the typical learning style most Duke students are used to. If you excel in lecture-based classes, this will be outside of your comfort zone. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is definitely not your typical Duke class. I appreciated it because it was a refreshing departure from some of my more "normative" large lecture courses. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was amazing in opening my mind to the real world and providing a break from the college structure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will definitely push you to escape the limitations of your comfort zone. There may be times where you will feel uncomfortable with the movements and physical activities conducted in the class, but ultimately if you engage, you will learn and grow as a student and as a thinker and activist. Teachers do a good job ensuring that the classroom is a safe space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage students to take this course because it helps them to realize the situation they are in and how to use your imagination to work for a better future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will change the way you think and view radical ideas. One quote from Brookes and the reading that will forever stick with me is "dance is thought." As a dancer, this quote stays in my heart as I perform and practice every time. I have always battled internally whether my movements lead to my dance moves or my movements led to the feeling of liberation I always have when I'm dancing. But through this course, I realized that dance is purely just my thinking; movement is thought. This course taught me how to view my dancing career and also imagine for liberation. As the professors said, radical imaginations are always needed for real change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be increasingly aware of the way societal systems norm us and how we are subject to those normative ideologies; I learned how to connect and tap into my body as a means of thought; I practices the skill of thinking in an imaginative and creative way to approach social change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked this class because I learned a lot about social injustices and social problems. Three things that I learned that really resonated with me are the connection between how diabled people are treated and the treatment of animals, the act up movement in the 80s and 90s surrounding HIV/AIDS, and how some children are at a huge disadvantage when it comes to access to education.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about how movement is a form of communication and can be used for activism, thought, and expression. We also learned a lot about different activist groups and what they did. We also learned how to think outside the box of what we think of as normal when it comes to restructuring and changing the systems we have in place to try to better our society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to have productive discourse on politically motivated topics, particularly in an environment with various opinions on certain subjects. I also learned much about the connection between thought, emotion, and movement. To add to that, I understand my body and how I can utilize moving it as a tool to gain a deeper understanding of myself and my perceived environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to use my body to think and what it means to "embody" concepts. I feel more connected to my body now. I also learned what the "soma" is and how philosophy, ethics, and neuroscience can inform how we process trauma, think, and perpetuate societal norms. I also know much more about the AIDS movement, criminal justice reform and reparations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into what types of issues are out in the world and I got to develop my perspective on those illuminating problems. I learned how to think outside of the box and be creative in thinking up solutions to change the narrative, the societal norms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problem-solving skills, knowledge of current events and topics that are currently affecting society, and insight into how these problems can be solved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really made me think about my life and the position I'm in. It really made me want to be more aware of what is happening around me, especially what is going on in the scenes around social injustice and art. I learned a lot about the history of social injustices like sexism, racism, and classism. This class helped me to think using my body and know what it feels like to getting closer to merging the mind and body into one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a hardcore STEM enthusiast, I never in my life thought I would sit through a small public policy seminar during my first semester of college. But, looking in retrospect, this seminar was my one of my favorite classes that I have taken. First, I learned to think outside the "norm." During class, we called our professors by their first names and sat on bean bags and wool carpets instead of chairs. We had wild discussions ranging from prison abolition to using our body to connect with our thoughts ("dance is thought"). These discussions made me think outside the box and realize that if I continue to imagine the seemingly radical ideas, maybe one day it will become a reality. Secondly, I learned how to analyze texts and lead discussions/debates that differed from my personal, political, and ethical views. Our discussion section was very close-knit and welcoming, and I learned to value not only sharing my own opinions but also listening to other's viewpoints and peacefully debating controversial topics. Finally, I learned the value of exploring various ways to approach radical ideas. For instance, throughout class, we used our body to get in touch with our radical view of the world. This was very stimulating and eye-opening in that movement can change our thoughts and be used as a vehicle to explore the most radical ideas that are subconsciously in our brain.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very available to talk, and facilitated deeply thought provoking discussions throughout each class and through the reading. This allowed me to analyze to a deeper level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that they definately did a good job having us engage in class. It was refreshing to have teachers who also spoke about their opinions and ideas in class as well as leaving space for us students to discuss. the class was definitely not lecture based which I appreciated. It was a conversation between everyone including our professors which I really liked.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors did a great job of pushing our thinking to the next level by always asking us questions to deepen our thoughts. They also did fun things in the dance studio, like setting up sculptures and art around it to create an environment that pushes the boundaries of what we see as normal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think this class did a fabulous job of balancing productive discourse with artistic elements of movement. Having an approximately 50/50 split between discussions and movement breaks kept the class interesting, informative, and fun. I would say the overall structure of the class is refreshing from the typical lecture style, so I recommend keeping it the same in future classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the class felt conversational and the instructors were overall very open to new ideas or even tangential conversations. I also liked that we were able to call them by their first names as it created a greater sense of intimacy. I also appreciated that the class was held in a dance studio as it was a great canvas to build upon as we moved, built, and imagined.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The ways the instructors facilitate my learning by giving me the opportunity to learn on my own in a capacity of no-hand holding of figuring out what is important to me and what I as an individual can do in the here and now. I love the weekly reflections of seeing different modes and solutions to societal issues that impact us in a small or little way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructors made classroom environment very comfortable and safe, applying unconventional methods (like sitting on the floor, setting up classroom in a strange way, referring to profs by first name, and using movement to engage the body and the mind during class time) to challenge what is deemed "normal". I liked the casual, comfortable environment of the class and felt that it helped students engage more with the material and think outside the box.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The part of the course that I really enjoyed the most was the movement exercises that we did. We were lead in an exercise typically meant to bridge the gap between body and mind and use our imaginations to do so. We were challenged to do movements we've never felt before and experience new feelings. The instructors used these exercises to expand our imaginations. We learned what it was like to imagine new ideas from the texts that we read in class and how people in the past have really thought outside of the box in order to address social injustices. The instructors gave us a good amount of reading material but let us interpret our own understanding in discussion posts. I think I would keep these same methods of instruction in the future, except that some weeks had a large amount of reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both instructors were very very VERY welcoming, friendly, and easy to approach. I even turned to Brookes for personal advice and had a conversation about my love for arts and how I could explore that throughout college. The professors were genuinely SO caring about each and every one of their students, and I will always be on a lookout if they teach more courses in the future. They not only helped me grow as a student and a thinker, but as a person.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how I was incorrectly thinking about my anatomy/proper use of my body in movement. I how to correct my mental body map (the way I understand my anatomy to look like and function in my head). I learned about how to paymore attention to my breath, gravity, and releasing tension. Most importantly, I learned how to think of my body as a whole rather than individual parts (which helped with relieving my pain from injuries).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.
